entry.title: Please delete - post format had errors
SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 2: Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products
entry.content:
Introduction:

In Part 1(SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products) of this blog series, we explored the fundamentals of Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). Now, in Part 2, we dive into the practical aspect of extending SAP-managed Data Products, specifically, how to incorporate custom Y/Z fields into the standard SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Managed Data Products. If you have already enhanced the underlying CDS views or entities in your SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE) system before activating the corresponding data package or installing the intelligent application, the good news is that your custom fields will automatically flow into the Data Product upon activation. No additional steps required!

In this article, we‚Äôll walk through a common extension scenario involving Sales Order and Billing/Invoice CDS views or SAP Data Products:

 

Data ProductData Source CDS
Sales OrderI_SalesOrder
Sales Order ItemI_SalesOrderItem
Billing Document ItemI_BillingDocumentItemDEX
 

Steps to Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products Using Key User Extensibility

1. Set Up Adaptation Transport Organizer (ATO): As a prerequisite, ensure ATO is configured to support key user extensions in your system.

2. Add Custom Fields via SAP Fiori App: Open the Custom Fields and Logic app in SAP Fiori and create the required Y/Z custom fields.

How to find business context? Use Tcode: SCFD_REGISTRY

Select Business Context for SD_SALESDOC for Sales Document (Order) and SD_SALESDOCITEM for Sales Document Item.

Similarly  select Business Context SD_BILLINGDOCITEM for Billing Document Item 

Fill the custom field technical details like label, id, data type etc.

3. Publish Custom Fields:After creating the fields, publish them. This step will automatically append your custom fields to the underlying SAP standard ABAP tables.

Publish the field, below one is shown for CampaignID which is added to billing document item.

Likewise it can be done for Sales order (ZZ1_Custom1) and Sales order item (ZZ1_Custom2) custom fields extension.

After above steps custom fields should be appended to standard ABAP tables: VBAK, VBAP and VBRP in our scenario.

VBAK:

 VBAP:

VBRP:

4. Extend the CDS Views or Entities :Enhance the relevant CDS views/entities to include the newly created custom fields.
If the CDS view is listed in the Extensibility Registry (T-code: SCFD_REGISTRY), use Data Source Extensions, this is the recommended approach before resorting to manual CDS view or entity extensions, as demonstrated below.
Alright, we will use CDS extension to include the added and published custom fields:

4.1: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrder to include ZZ_CUSTOM1 field. You can also view the data definitions which got created, when custom fields where published using the Fiori App Custom Fields and Logic.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDER'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrder'
extend view I_SalesOrder with ZEXTEND_SALESORDER
{
ZZ1_Custom1_SDH as ZZ_CUSTOM1
}

Once extension view is activated, you can now test the CDS extractor/view (SE16N):

4.2: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrderItem to include ZZ1_CUSTOM2 field. You can also view in the Eclipse ADT perspective, what CDS extensions have been created for the CDS view, click on the spiral icon.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDITEM'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrderItem'
extend view I_SalesOrderItem with ZEXTEND_SALESORDERITEM
{
ZZ1_Custom2_SDI as ZZ1_Custom2
}

Click on spiral icon:

4.3: Extend CDS Entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX to include ZZ_CampaignID field. 
Note: In previous scenarios, we extended CDS views; in this case, we are extending a CDS entity. CDS entity does not have SQL view created.

extend view entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX with
{
  _Extension.ZZ1_CampaignID_BDI as ZZ_CampaignID

}

5. Validate Data in CDS Views/Entities: Test the extended CDS views to confirm that the custom fields are populated with data (assuming relevant business logic is in place and transactional data has been updated). e.g. For Sales Order extension use released BAdIs enhancement spot ES_SD_SLS_EXTEND, classic ABAP has user-exit MV45AFZZ (this is out of scope for this blog).

In previous using SE16N we validated that fields are populated on the extended views or entities. 

6. Activate the Data Package in the SAP BDC Cockpit :Proceed to activate the related data package that uses the extended CDS views and has data products of interest.
Note: SAP-managed Data products cannot be activated individually. They only can be activated via Intelligent Application or on data package level. That means that all the data products within the data package or Intelligent Application are activated in one step.

Data Package: SAP Sales Data Products( SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) has the Data Products 1.Sales Order and 2. Billing Documet.

Once you activate the data package, on the SAP S/4HANA side you can check in the Tcode DHADM for subscription, data replication etc.

Transfer jobs overview:

 

APRS is pushing to target HANA Data Lake Files i.e. SAP BDC Foundational services (FOS) layer.

Target HDLF file path:

Give some time based on the data volume of the data products for the data package to become active. 

7. Install the Data Product: Install the SAP-managed data product corresponding to the activated data package.
Currently, Delta-Share or zero-copy works only with Databricks. In SAP Datasphere, these data products are replicated from the FOS layer into the SAP Datasphere Ingestion Space (SAP managed). In the future, SAP Datasphere will also support Delta-Share.

Prerequisite step:  Add space WS_IT so that you can install the data product (via sharing from the system ingestion space).

Next, we will install data products into the SAP Datasphere WS_IT Space (User Modeling Space).
This process creates a data product share from the SAP-managed Ingestion Space to the user-managed WS_IT Space in our scenario.

Go to SAP Datasphere ‚Üí Catalog & Marketplace.

Now, we have successfully installed the Data Products.

8. Preview Data in Local Table: Finally, preview the data within the Data Product‚Äôs local table to confirm that the custom fields are available and populated with the data.
We can view in the WS_IT space, all the data products are installed (shared).

If we click on Billing Document Item data product, then it will navigate to SAP managed Datasphere Ingestion Space RI4400(SAP-Managed).

Great, the data products, now enhanced with your custom (Z) fields, have been successfully installed and are ready for to be used in Datasphere modeling or delta-share with Databricks.

Q: We need to extend an already installed data product. How should we handle this situation?

A: Currently, when you need to extend or change an existing data product, the process On the SAP S/4HANA source side, any changes you make will be handled within the existing framework. On the SAP BDC side, however, you must either deactivate the entire data package or uninstall the intelligent application and then activate or reinstall it to incorporate the new changes to the data product. It is not the most efficient way to handle a small change of adding new field to the data product. The product team is aware of this and is working on a solution to provide more granular control at the data product level, which would allow for more targeted updates in the future.

Summary:

In this blog, we saw how to extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products by adding custom fields and making them available in SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere. We learned how to use the Custom Fields and Logic app, extend CDS entities, and replicate the updated data by data product activation. Things are improving and getting rapidly in the product, and I will do my best to keep this blog updated with the latest changes. Happy Learning üôÇ!

entry.title: Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration
entry.content:
In the fast-paced world of business today, it's crucial to connect traditional EDI systems with modern cloud ERP systems for streamlined operations. This blog takes a closer look at an integration fllow that handles inbound EDI messages, transforms them into SOAP format and facilitate effortless communication with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Let's explore how this approach changes data formats and guarantees a reliable,standards-complaint integration between legacy and cloud systems.

Note:  For detailed steps on creating and exporting the required MIG and MAG files used in this integration, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

Step-by-Step Guide: EDI to SOAP Inbound Integration Flow

Here‚Äôs a detailed look at the entire integration flow (iFlow) for processing EDI to SOAP inbound messages. This iFlow covers all the essential steps and components needed to receive, validate, transform, and route EDI messages into SOAP format, ensuring a smooth connection to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Step 1: Receive EDI Data via AS2

To initiate the integration, configure the AS2 adapter to receive inbound EDI messages. This configuration supports secure and reliable data transfer in B2B scenarios involving EDI communication.

Note: For detailed steps on setting up the AS2 adapter, refer to the blog: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration ‚Äì SAP Community

Step 2: Add Start Message

Add a Start Message event to initiate the integration flow when EDI data is received through AS2.

Step 3: Add EDI Splitter

Add an EDI Splitter for handling incoming EDI messages. It breaks them down into individual transactions, checks their structure for validity, and can also generate acknowledgments if necessary.

Important:All the XSD and mapping files mentioned in this flow( ASC-X12 XSD, preproc.xsl, and others)‚Äîare created and exported during the MIG and MAG setup process in SAP Integration Advisor.
For a step-by-step guide on generating and exporting these files, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File
  1. To upload ASC-X12 XSD file, navigate to the X12 tab in the EDI Splitter configuration. You‚Äôll find the file in the Source folder that was extracted during the MAG export.
  2. This file outlines the structure of the incoming EDI message, allowing the splitter to accurately parse and process the X12 message.

Step 4: Add Router

Now, let‚Äôs add a Router following the EDI Splitter. This step is crucial for separating EDI messages from acknowledgement messages, especially if you‚Äôve enabled the generation of acknowledgements in the splitter.

Let's define two routing paths:

1. Acknowledgement Route: This route deals with acknowledgement messages independently.

In the Processing tab, you‚Äôll see:

Expression Type Options:

  • XML: This is used when the message is formatted in XML.
  • NON_XML: This is for messages that aren‚Äôt in XML format, where routing is based on the message headers.

We opt for NON_XML since the acknowledgement message isn‚Äôt in XML, so the router checks the message headers instead of the XML content.

 Condition: ${header.EDI_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT} = 'true'

 

2. Default Route: Responsible for processing standard EDI messages.

No condition needed (processes all other messages)

Step 5: Integrate EDI to XML Converter

Now, let‚Äôs add an EDI to XML Converter to convert the EDI message into XML format.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File

  1. Navigate to the X12 tab and upload the ASC-X12.xsd file from the Source folder that you got from the MAG export.
  2. The ASC-X12 XSD file defines the structure of the incoming EDI message, enabling the EDI to XML Converter to accurately interpret and transform the EDI data into XML format.

Step 6: Include XSLT Mapping (Pre-processing)

Next up, we‚Äôll add XSLT Mapping to handle data preprocessing and transformation.

  • Upload preproc.xsl File
  1. Under the Processing tab, upload the preproc.xsl File from the Source folder extracted from the MAG export.
  2.  This step modifies the XML structure created from the EDI message, ensuring it aligns with the expected input format for message mapping.

Step 7: Add XML Validator (Post-processing)

Add an XML Validator to validate the pre-processed XML.

  • Upload X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd File
  1. Navigate to the Validation tab and upload the X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd file from the Source folder you extracted from the MAG export.
  2. This step makes sure that the transformed XML adheres to the expected schema before you proceed to message mapping, helping you identify any structural issues early on.

Step 8: Implement XSLT Mapping (Main Mapping)

Let‚Äôs add an XSLT Mapping to transform the validated EDI XML into the target SOAP message structure.

  • Upload Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl File

  1. Under the Processing tab, you‚Äôll need to upload the Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl file from the root folder of the exported MAG zip file.
  2. This main mapping file, which was generated by SAP Integration Advisor (IA), is crucial for transforming the data into the right format for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Step 9: Apply XSLT Mapping (Post-processing)

Add an XSLT Mapping to adjust the mapped XML output to the final structure required by the target system.

  • Upload SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl File
  1. Head over to the Processing tab and upload the SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl file from the Target MIG folder.
  2. This ensures the transformed XML matches the exact format expected by the target system for successful processing.

Step 10: Add SOAP Receiver Adapter

Use the SOAP Receiver Adapter to connect to SAP S/4HANA and transmit the transformed XML payload over a SOAP-based web service. This adapter ensures that the data is encapsulated in a SOAP envelope and sent to the appropriate endpoint.

  • Address:Enter the SOAP service endpoint URL provided by your target system.

  • URL to WSDL:Click on Browse and upload the .wsdl file that corresponds to your target SOAP service. CPI will automatically fill in the Service, Endpoint, and Operation Name fields based on the WSDL information.
  • Authentication: Basic
  • Credential Name: Enter the Credential Name of the User Credentials you set up in Security Material.

This marks the end of the configuration for the EDI-to-SOAP inbound integration flow. With this iFlow in action, incoming EDI messages are handled efficiently and routed to the S/4HANA target system in the required SOAP format.

Disclaimer:
All the views and opinions in this blog are my own and are made in my personal capacity. SAP shall not be responsible or liable for any of the contents published in this blog.

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is ‚Äúclean core‚Äù?

Let‚Äôs dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: An SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called ‚Äúclean core extensibility‚Äù. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, as the Public Cloud Edition cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the public cloud, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model ‚Äì Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP S/4HANA, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core‚Äîdecoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability‚Äîremain essential.

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP S/4HANA system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP S/4HANA, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP S/4HANA

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes ‚Äì all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP‚Äôs AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP S/4HANA.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP‚Äôs programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP S/4HANA and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you‚Äôre involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: Managing Legacy Files for India GSTR reports in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance
entry.content:
Introduction 

When implementing SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for GST reporting in India, it may be necessary to store legacy GST-filed documents and responses (for example, GSTR1 filling json, GSTR3B etc.) from the GSTN for future reference and audit purposes. This blog presents a practical approach to manually storing and managing previously reported files within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance by using Attachment section in the Generated Run. 

Disclaimer: This document does not replace a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Part 1: Technical Prerequisites 

Step 1: Create a Custom Report Definition 

Begin by setting up a custom report definition to manage historical files. This involves: 

  • Custom Report Definition: Tailor a report specifically for historical data. 
  • Corresponding Report Category: Categorize the report appropriately. 
  • Custom Entity: Create if necessary. 

‚ÄØfor example, ZIN_GSTR1 or YIN_GSTR1 etc. 

Note: Either you can use the same Z or Y report created above, across multiple GST reports or you can create a new report based on the functionality. 

Refer to SAP Documentation for detailed instructions on defining statutory reports SAP Documentation ‚Äì Define Statutory Reports for creating above-mentioned objects. 

Step 2: Define a Schema 

During setting up the document section in report definition, you must specify a schema or ABAP structure to define the document layout. Use the following sample JSON structure to facilitate file uploads: 

{ 

    "title": "India GSTR Reporting", 

    "type": "object", 

    "properties": { 

        "CompanyCode": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[0-9]{4}$", 

            "description": "4-digit company code" 

        }, 

        "Country": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[a-zA-Z]{2}$", 

            "description": "2-letter ISO country code (e.g., IN or In)" 

        } 

    } 

}

Save this schema as a .json file and upload it during report definition configuration. 

Note: The same schema can be used across multiple GST reports. 

Step 3: Configure Document Mapping 

Assign static (literal) values for required fields to simplify the upload process, such as: 

  • Company Code: 1810 
  • Country: IN 

 

 

‚ÄØ 

Part 2: Storing Attachments in Document and Reporting Compliance 

Step 1: Generate a Report Run 

Create a new reporting run for the relevant period. This serves as a placeholder for document storage. 

Note: This run is intended only to facilitate document storage. Make sure to consider any storage limitations related to the attachment service. 

Disclaimer: It is not a substitute for a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Step 2: Navigate to the Run 

Locate your custom report and the run you created in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance application. 

 

 

Step 3: Access the Attachments Tab 

Switch to the Attachments tab within the selected run. 

 

 

Step 4: Upload Your Historical File 

Click on Upload and select the desired historical file from your computer

 

 

Step 5: Save the Attachment 

Click Save Attachment to securely store the file in the system for future reference. 

 

 

Conclusion 

By utilizing custom report definitions and the Attachments feature, organizations can centralize access to both new and historical statutory filing records within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. This method ensures a consistent and auditable compliance process, regardless of your adoption timeline or transitions between reporting solutions.

entry.title: How to Prioritize Inventory with ABC Analysis in SAP EWM
entry.content:
Hi SAP SCM Community!

In this blog, I want to provide information about ABC Analysis in EWM and also give an example of its use.

Introduction

ABC Analysis is a technique used in SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) to categorize inventory items based on their importance. This classification helps in optimizing inventory management by focusing on the most critical items:

Category A: High-value items with low turnover rates. These items require more stringent inventory control and monitoring.

Category B: Moderate-value items with moderate turnover rates. These items need balanced control measures.

Category C: Low-value items with high turnover rates. These items require simpler control measures due to their lower impact on overall inventory value.

 

For this we can go to the Transaction Code: /SCWM/ABC

 

We have three main part in the selection screen:

Location & Product Selection ‚Äì In this part you can select warehouse number (mandatory criteria), party entitled to dispose, product, warehouse product group and also If you want to limit the products that are analyzed to only those products with warehouse tasks, select Exclude Products w/o WTs:

I prefer, restrict your selection with specific selection criteria for better performance.

Confirmed Product Warehouse Task Selection -  In this part we can give specific confirmation date for the warehouse tasks, also warehouse process category, warehouse process type, source storage type, destination storage type and alternative unit of measure. Due to your requirements you can use these filters too:

Analysis Strategy Selection ‚Äì Firstly we can choose which analysis we want: It can be number of confirmed warehouse tasks or quantity moved:

After that we can set how many categories we want ‚Äì Normally, businesses use 3 category:

Also, we can increase the number of categories up to 12:

 

First two parts of Analysis strategy selection is about how we can analyse our warehouse data:

After ABC Analysis we can change three product master data indicator:

  • Putaway control indicator
  • Storage section indicator, either on warehouse level or for specific storage types
  • Cycle counting indicator

 

In the last part of the selection screen is if we want to use update this indicators in background we can click this box:

Also, we can use this box for scheduling job for update master data indicators.

 

Example of using ABC Analysis in EWM

Go to /SCWM/ABC and choose warehouse number, products in that warehouse number and confirmation date for warehouse tasks. As an analysis strategy I select the number of confirmed warehouse tasks, three categories and in the percent basis. Also, I want to update master data for the specific criteria:  for products which is in category A, add/update Putaway strategy (PUTW), and based their category add/update cycle counting indicator:

 

After run this selection screen we can see ABC Analysis Result. The screen displays only the products that are actually to be updated. (In this case New PACI and New CC Ind. field values will be added/updated to the master data of these products.) If you want to display all items, choose All <-> With Changes:

After this you can see one more line which is not have any changes in the master data:

 

Before updating the master data let‚Äôs look at one of the products data in /SCWM/MAT1:

Based on the availability of the product master data  in /SCWM/MAT1 you can choose Display/Change or Create:

 

In the Warehouse Data tab you can see Cycle Counting Indicator and Putaway Control fields which are empty:

If you want to update master data for the products you can click the button on the below (Save Selected Updates) and choose which updates do you want, in this scenario I choose All Updates:

Then you can go back to /SCWM/MAT1 and check the updates, so now Cycle Counting Indicator and Putaway Control fields have values which we save in the /SCWM/ABC:

Thanks for reading, if this was helpful or if you have any questions, please leave a comment.

#WarehouseManagement #ABCAnalysis #EWM

 

Best Regards,

Eldar Ibrahimov

Senior EWM Consultant

entry.title: ABAP Extensibility Guide ‚Äì Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
End of 2022 we launched ABAP Cloud and published the new ABAP extensibility guide. This guide is the best starting point for overview of ABAP Cloud development model and ABAP-based extensibility options for SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on-premise. The last update of the extensibility guide took place in May 2023 where we incorporated the feedback of early adaptors of ABAP Cloud in real SAP S/4HANA systems.

A key concept for extensibility in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on-premise outlined in the ABAP extensibility guide was the 3-tier extensibility model. This model described how ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP can co-exist within a single system: tier 1 contained ABAP Cloud on-stack extensions, as well as any developments with SAP Build on SAP BTP for side-by-side extensions. Tier 2 served to address gaps, providing mechanisms to mitigate necessary publicly released SAP APIs not yet available in tier 1. Finally, tier 3 encompassed classic ABAP extensions. Only tier 1 (and tier 2, when using recommended SAP objects) was considered as clean core. In contrast, tier 3 was classified as ‚Äúnot clean.‚Äù The ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness controlled the usage of classic ABAP in custom extensions.

The main objective of the clean core dimension Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA on-premise deployments is decoupling of custom extensions from SAP standard via use of ABAP Cloud and reliable development and extension technologies to reach upgrade stability. On the way to clean core, dealing with the classic ABAP custom code represents a challenge for SAP customers and partners. Multiple customer and partner interactions showed that the binary classification of custom code in the 3-tier extensibility model in ‚Äúclean core‚Äù and ‚Äúnot clean core‚Äù and governance based on ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness were too restrictive and not applicable for systems with a lot of existing custom code developed with classic ABAP. Besides this there are also new custom extensions which need to be implemented with classic ABAP because for example the related SAP application area is not sufficiently covered by publicly released SAP APIs or is implemented with SAP GUI based technologies and frameworks. On the other hand, many of underlying SAP classic ABAP technologies, like ABAP List Viewer for example, incorporate an implementation stability which most likely will bring minimum upgrade risks and can be still utilized in classic ABAP developments.

The new Clean core extensibility white paper introduced by SAP incorporates evolution of the current 3-tier extensibility model with binary decisions on clean core to more detailed assessment of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept, allowing you as SAP customers and partners stepwise transformation to clean core at your own pace.

In a nutshell:

  • Level A are the cleanest custom extensions built either on-stack with ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side using any option of SAP Build on SAP BTP ‚Äì ABAP Cloud, CAP or low-code/no-code tools

           Levels B-D relate to all classic ABAP developments and can be reached as follows:

  • Level B can be achieved by custom extensions that comply with SAP recommendations for the use of classic ABAP development technologies and the frameworks offered as classic SAP APIs
  • Level C contains custom extensions which cannot be qualified for Level B because of usage of arbitrary SAP internal objects. Under the condition that dedicated checks are performed before the release upgrade (following the changelog for SAP objects approach), these custom extensions can be considered conditionally clean.
  • Level D is not clean core and includes custom extensions with severe violations of SAP development recommendations like modifications, usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension technologies (e.g. implicit enhancements).

Following the new clean core extensibility guidance we have updated the ABAP extensibility guide with technical guidelines which are in line and support the clean core level concept for the classification of custom extensions.

Summary of technical ABAP extensibility guidelines for clean core


How the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) supports clean core level concept

Main updates for transformation of 3-tier extensibility model to clean core extensibility based on clean core level concept (see the activity log on page 1 of the ABAP extensibility guide for details):

  • Change technical guidelines for extensibility from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development and classic ABAP development
  • Explain classic SAP APIs and their matching to clean core levels
  • Provide ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of classic ABAP development for clean core
  • Explain relation of custom code use cases to clean core levels
  • Describe changelog for SAP objects approach for assessment of upgrade stability of custom code using SAP internal objects
  • Change transformation options for existing custom code from 3-tier extensibility model to ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP developments

Supporting the clean core extensibility and clean core level concept with these technical guidelines for ABAP extensibility is a next significant step forward to support your clean core transformation at your own speed.

If you have already set up the 3-tier extensibility model and are following clean core development practices, you might be wondering if the new guidance changes everything. Good news ‚Äî you are already on the right track! The new clean core level concept simply provides enhanced guidance for everything you developed in tier 3 with classic ABAP.

If you now want to learn more about the refined clean core extensibility guidance and clean core levels, read the Clean core extensibility whitepaper.

For more information about ABAP Cloud and recommendations for classic ABAP developments, classic APIs, ABAP test cockpit setup and behavior for governance of clean core development supporting the clean core levels switch directly to the updated ABAP extensibility guide.

In addition, you can also use the updated ABAP Cloud - Extensibility slide deck . To get your questions answered use the ABAP Cloud FAQ and the ABAP Development community.

We will continue our ABAP Cloud and clean core collaboration with customers and partners and will share the new learnings and provide new updates. After this update related to the adaption of the new clean core extensibility model the next major update of the ABAP extensibility guide planned for Q4/2025 will focus on enhancements in ABAP custom code management tools and ABAP AI capabilities. Stay tuned!

entry.title: GIS and SAP Integration ‚Äì critical for Oil and Gas Companies
entry.content:
Dynamic alignment sheets facilitate the maintenance process

Today‚Äôs blog focuses on the midstream segment of the oil and gas industry, where the transportation of oil and gas plays a critical role. Companies aim to optimize field asset management by maintaining accurate digital twins of pipelines and related assets. Traditionally, however, different business and IT systems are used to represent these assets: SAP systems manage financial and maintenance data, while GIS systems handle technical specifications and location intelligence. To streamline asset registration and improve efficiency, it is essential to eliminate duplicate data entry, which not only wastes time but also increases the risk of errors.

VertiGIS Integrator streamlines the asset registration process by enabling efficient synchronization between GIS and SAP systems. Assets can be initially created in SAP and synchronized to GIS, where only the geographical location and select technical attributes are recorded. Conversely, for assets where GIS serves as the primary system, the integration ensures these assets are seamlessly transferred to SAP after their creation in GIS. This bi-directional workflow enables a highly efficient and integrated asset registration process.

With GIS and SAP now fully integrated, businesses can leverage map-centric workflows to enhance operational efficiency. A key example is in maintenance processes, particularly the creation of notifications. For instance, when a pipeline malfunction, such as corrosion, is identified in the field, it is essential to pinpoint the exact location along the pipeline for accurate notification placement.

Traditionally, oil and gas companies have relied on alignment sheets to document various properties or events along linear assets using linear references, such as meters or kilometers. VertiGIS has modernized this process with its VertiGIS Inline software module, bringing alignment sheets into the digital era. This module allows users to dynamically analyze pipeline-related data through a combination of standard maps and linear-referenced properties displayed below the pipeline. Using VertiGIS Studio Workflow technology, user actions can be configured through an intuitive drag-and-drop interface. This enables end users to create SAP notifications at specific linear reference points (e.g., kilometer 3.2) or precise map coordinates (X, Y). This map-centric approach simplifies and improves the user experience for creating SAP notifications.

The interface displays the pipeline on a map, with a dynamic alignment sheet below. Users can efficiently create SAP notifications or other custom events at specific points, such as kilometer 3.2.

In addition, VertiGIS supports map-centric mobile workflows that integrate SAP and GIS systems. Field workers can use mobile applications, such as VertiGIS Studio Mobile, to create notifications or manage work orders directly in the field. These notifications are then automatically synced with the SAP system in near real-time, ensuring accurate and up-to-date information across business systems.

If you have any questions or would like to find out more, please contact me at https://www.linkedin.com/in/florianbrandidohrn/ or florian.brandi-dohrn@vertigis.com.
